jurisdiction.name: South Carolina
jurisdiction.transparency_law: South Carolina Freedom of Information Act

validation_metadata.verification_method: Direct review of SC Code Title 30, Chapter 4

rights_of_access.description: This chapter must be construed liberally in favor of openness. This establishes South Carolina's strong presumption favoring transparency.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to all FOIA interpretations; courts and agencies must construe law broadly favoring disclosure
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Explicit liberal construction requirement - ambiguities resolved in favor of access; supports maximum disclosure principle
rights_of_access.request_tips: Cite mandate: 'SC Code § 30-4-110(A) requires liberal construction in favor of openness. Any ambiguity must be resolved favoring disclosure of [records].'

rights_of_access.subcategory: Universal Right to Inspect or Copy
rights_of_access.description: Any person has a right to inspect or copy any public record of a public body, except as otherwise provided by exemptions, in accordance with reasonable rules concerning time and place of access.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to any person; reasonable time and place rules; subject only to statutory exemptions
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public records in South Carolina
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: No residency requirement - 'any person' includes non-residents; dual right to inspect OR copy provides flexibility
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert: 'SC Code § 30-4-30(A) grants any person the right to inspect or copy public records. Please provide access to [records] under this statutory right.'

rights_of_access.description: A public body shall respond to a request within fifteen calendar days by providing the record, providing a written explanation for delay in providing the record, or providing written explanation stating the basis for refusal to provide the record.
rights_of_access.conditions: 15 calendar days (not business days) for response; must provide records, explain delay, or deny with basis; response must be substantive
rights_of_access.applies_to: All FOIA requests in South Carolina
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Calendar days, not business days - approximately 2 weeks; response options preserve transparency even when delays occur
rights_of_access.request_tips: Cite deadline: 'SC Code § 30-4-30(C) requires response within 15 calendar days. Please confirm receipt and respond by providing records, explaining any delay, or stating refusal basis.'

rights_of_access.description: If a request for records is granted, the records shall be furnished as promptly as reasonably possible, but no later than thirty calendar days from the date of the request, unless the request is for records that are more than twenty-four months old, in which case the public body has up to thirty-five calendar days to furnish the records.
rights_of_access.conditions: 30 calendar days maximum for current records (under 24 months old); 35 calendar days for older records (24+ months); must furnish promptly as reasonably possible within these maximums
rights_of_access.applies_to: Granted FOIA requests in South Carolina
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Clear maximum deadlines; older records get additional 5 days recognizing retrieval challenges; 'as promptly as reasonably possible' requires production before deadline when feasible
rights_of_access.request_tips: For current records: 'SC Code § 30-4-30(D) requires records furnished within 30 calendar days, as promptly as reasonably possible. Please provide by [specific date within 30 days].' For old records: 'These records are over 24 months old, giving you 35 calendar days under SC Code § 30-4-30(D).'

rights_of_access.description: A public body may establish fees for the actual costs of search, retrieval, and reproduction of records. If the cost of reproduction is greater than twenty-five dollars, the public body may require a deposit not exceeding twenty-five percent of the estimated cost prior to searching for or reproducing the records.
rights_of_access.conditions: Fees limited to actual costs only; covers search, retrieval, and reproduction; deposit up to 25% when cost exceeds $25
rights_of_access.applies_to: All fee charges for South Carolina public records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Actual cost limitation prevents inflated fees; deposit mechanism protects agencies from non-payment but capped at reasonable 25%; must provide cost estimate justifying deposit
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge excessive fees: 'SC Code § 30-4-30(B) limits fees to actual costs of search, retrieval, and reproduction. Please provide itemized breakdown showing actual costs, not estimates or overhead.'

rights_of_access.description: Any citizen of South Carolina may apply to the circuit court for a declaratory judgment, an injunction, or a writ of mandamus to enforce the provisions of FOIA. Suit may be brought in county where public body has principal place of business or where violation alleged to have occurred.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be South Carolina citizen; venue in county of public body or violation; declaratory judgment, injunction, or mandamus available
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Multiple judicial remedies available; flexible venue options; citizenship requirement limits enforcement to SC residents
rights_of_access.request_tips: Warn of judicial option: 'As a South Carolina citizen, SC Code § 30-4-100(A) grants me the right to seek circuit court enforcement through declaratory judgment, injunction, or mandamus.'

rights_of_access.description: The court in its discretion may award reasonable attorney's fees and other costs of litigation to the plaintiff if he substantially prevails. The court may also award fees to defendant if plaintiff's case is frivolous, malicious, or wholly without merit.
rights_of_access.conditions: Discretionary award; plaintiff must substantially prevail; defendant may recover if case frivolous; covers attorney fees and litigation costs
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Fee-shifting makes enforcement financially viable for citizens; two-way fee provision discourages frivolous suits while protecting legitimate claims
rights_of_access.request_tips: When considering litigation: 'SC Code § 30-4-100(B) provides for attorney fee recovery if I substantially prevail. This makes pursuing my rights financially feasible.'

rights_of_access.description: A public body that arbitrarily and capriciously violates the provisions of FOIA is subject to a civil fine of five hundred dollars for each violation.
rights_of_access.conditions: Requires finding of arbitrary and capricious conduct; $500 fine per violation; applies to public body, not individual officials
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Monetary penalty provides accountability; arbitrary and capricious standard requires more than mere error - willful or unreasonable conduct
rights_of_access.request_tips: Warn of penalties: 'SC Code § 30-4-100(C) imposes $500 civil fines for arbitrary and capricious FOIA violations. Please ensure your decision is supported by law to avoid penalties.'

rights_of_access.description: The provisions of this chapter are in addition to other provisions of law, and do not limit rights guaranteed by the State Constitution and laws of South Carolina or the United States Constitution and laws.
rights_of_access.conditions: FOIA provides minimum baseline; other constitutional and statutory rights remain available; FOIA does not restrict other access rights
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public records access in South Carolina
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: FOIA is floor, not ceiling - requesters may invoke other constitutional or statutory access rights beyond FOIA; protects against agencies claiming FOIA as sole access mechanism
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert broader rights: 'SC Code § 30-4-110(B) establishes FOIA as additional to, not limiting, other constitutional and statutory rights. I may assert other access rights beyond FOIA.'

rights_of_access.description: An action to enforce any provision of this chapter must be commenced within one year after the person knew or should have known of the act or omission alleged to have violated this chapter.
rights_of_access.conditions: One year from knowledge of violation or constructive knowledge; applies to all FOIA enforcement actions
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Generous one-year window (vs. 60-90 days in many states); runs from knowledge, not violation date; accommodates delayed discovery
rights_of_access.request_tips: Note timeline: 'SC Code § 30-4-165 provides one year from when I knew or should have known of this violation to commence enforcement action. I am evaluating whether to exercise this right.'
